results.title: [Remix: Women in science and technology]
results.brief_description:
This remix is a short film celebrating women in professional roles, including science, technology, aviation, mechanics and farming, sourced from footage in the ACMI Collection.

ACMI gratefully acknowledges the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Cargill Australia, Australian Wool Innovation Ltd., Rio Tinto, Elenor Peach, Yolanta Simmonds, Dept. of Employment, John Richardson, Wine Australia and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) costume
results.credit_line:
Cutting by Julie Skelton

Construction by Lyn Molloy

Courtesy Vice Media LLC, Blue-Tongue Films and Pariah Productions
results.material_description: new and re-purposed materials, cotton, linen, silk, leather, rubber, metal
results.brief_description: Judy’s everyday outfit is a tapestry of petticoat, skirt, apron, blouse and bodice. This layered approach that costume designer Edie Kurzer took allows different parts of the costume to be added or removed to create different looks, while reflecting the character’s downtrodden background.

constellations_primary.name: Women, crime and literature
constellations_primary.description: Judy & Punch draws on a classic puppet show that's been reframed by director Mirrah Foulkes as a feminist tale, much like the works that put women at the centre in this Constellation.

results.description: Poverty is rife in the world of Mirrah Foulkes’ Judy & Punch (2019). While Judy and Punch make a living performing marionette shows and have both everyday clothes and puppeteering outfits, most characters in the film, set in the 16th century, can only afford one set of threads. Judy’s everyday outfit is a tapestry of petticoat, skirt, apron, blouse and bodice. This layered approach that costume designer Edie Kurzer took allows different parts of the costume to be added or removed to create different looks, while reflecting the character’s downtrodden background.
description_for_label: Poverty is rife in the world of Mirrah Foulkes’ Judy & Punch (2019). While Judy and Punch make a living performing marionette shows and have both everyday clothes and puppeteering outfits, most characters in the film, set in the 16th century, can only afford one set of threads. Judy’s everyday outfit is a tapestry of petticoat, skirt, apron, blouse and bodice. This layered approach that costume designer Edie Kurzer took allows different parts of the costume to be added or removed to create different looks, while reflecting the character’s downtrodden background.

results.title: Electric sound
results.brief_description: The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction.

constellations_primary.name: Electric sound supercut: composers and their distinctive other worlds
constellations_primary.description: Electric sound is commonly associated with science fiction narratives for its auditory oddness, which has symbolised other worldly environments, the unconscious and the 1980s.

results.description: Specific types of movies have a specific sound. Overtime, these associations inevitably become subconscious. The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction, while husband and wife composers Bebe and Louis Barron are credited with creating the first fully realised electronic film score for 50s cult classic Forbidden Planet (1956). From deploying unconventional instruments to early looping and splicing techniques, the legacy of electric sound can still be found today in the works of composers like Danny Elfman.
description_for_label: Specific types of movies have a specific sound. Overtime, these associations inevitably become subconscious. The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction, while husband and wife composers Bebe and Louis Barron are credited with creating the first fully realised electronic film score for 50s cult classic Forbidden Planet (1956). From deploying unconventional instruments to early looping and splicing techniques, the legacy of electric sound can still be found today in the works of composers like Danny Elfman.

details.label: Curatorial sections
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-05. Sound and Colour → MI-05-AV02B
The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-05. Sound and Colour → MI-05-C02

results.title: Into a World of Colour
results.brief_description: Since the beginning of cinema, filmmakers experimented with colour and sound by hand-tinting frames and providing orchestral accompaniments. But it wasn’t until the early 20th century that ‘talkies’ truly changed the industry and glorious Technicolor ushered in the first golden age of cinema.

constellations_primary.name: Into a world of colour
constellations_primary.description: Filmmakers have been using colour as a method of storytelling since the first moving pictures. Colour can be used to signify emotion, intensify drama or to create a strong visual aesthetic.

results.title: Beautiful Ballarat [Edited Version]
results.brief_description:
This film captures the beauty found in the city of Ballarat through the seasons. Highlights include the Begonia Festival, the Avenue of Honour monument and other local historic landmarks.

The footage was filmed by John ‘Jack’ Anderson, and presented in this edited version with music added for an event held at the Regent Theatre in Ballarat on 5th March 2020, “Large as Life: celebrating the life John ‘Jack’ Anderson”.

results.title: The Last Tram
results.brief_description:
This film captured by John ‘Jack’ Anderson, documents the last tram ride through the city of Ballarat in 1971.

The footage was filmed in 1971, with titles and music added for an event held at the Regent Theatre in Ballarat on 5th March 2020, “Large as Life: celebrating the life John ‘Jack’ Anderson”.

results.title: We Dream of Networks
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson
fibre-tipped pen, fibre-tipped markers and gouache on paper
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: fibre-tipped pen, fibre-tipped markers and gouache on paper
results.brief_description:
Jess Johnson was born in Aotearoa/New Zealand in 1979, and lives and works in New York. Her drawing and installation practice is influenced by science fiction, language, culture and technology. In her drawings she depicts complex worlds that combine densely layered patterns, objects and figures within architectural settings. Johnson’s drawings are often displayed within constructed environments that act as physical portals into her speculative worlds. Her video collaborations with Simon Ward have involved translating her drawings into animated Virtual Reality, thus enabling her audience to have the simulated experience of entering the hypnotic realms depicted in her drawings. Jess Johnson’s work has been exhibited Internationally in solo exhibitions at; Jack Hanley Gallery, New York; Art Basel, Hong Kong; Nanzuka Gallery, Tokyo; Talbot Rice Gallery, Edinburgh; National Gallery of Australia; Museum of Contemporary Art, Australia; Auckland Art Gallery and Christchurch Art Gallery, New Zealand.

Jess Johnson is represented by Darren Knight Gallery, Sydney; Ivan Anthony Gallery, Auckland and Jack Hanley Gallery, New York
